description: From Middle English popinjay, popyngeay, popingay, popejay, from Anglo-Norman papegai, papejoie et al., (northern) Old French papejai (“parrot”), probably from Old Occitan papagay (compare Occitan papagai, Catalan papagai), ultimately from Arabic بَبْغَاء‎ (babḡāʔ, “parrot”), of imitative origin.

entries.meaning: (now archaic outside heraldry) A parrot. [from 14th c.; in heraldry from 15th c.]
(obsolete) A decorative image of a parrot on a tapestry, cloth etc. [14th–16th c.]
(dated) A vain, gaudy person; someone who is shallow or superficial. [from 16th c.]
(archery) A target to shoot at, typically stuffed with feathers or plumage. [from 16th c.]
(UK) The green woodpecker, Picus viridis. [from 19th c.]
